div.head: Editorial and Encoding Rationale and Methodology

div.p: For a detailed description of the kinds of webpages contained in the archive and their organization and navigation, see Plan of the Archive. The present note discusses the more fundamental rationale and methodology for editing and encoding the manuscripts. Past editorial appproaches are reviewed in History of the Bibliography and Editing of the Early Manuscripts.

The present note is divided into the following sections:
The Editorial Design of the Archive
Defining Works and Manuscripts
teiCorpus Markup and the Tension between Corpora and Works
Expressing the Materiality of Manuscripts
Collection and Anthology
Apparatuses, Notes, and Annotation
The Documentary Editorial Orientation in ERM
Transcription
The Private, Confidential, and Public in the Early Manuscripts
The Scope of the ERM Archive

div.head: The Editorial Design of the Archive
Defining Works and Manuscripts
div.p: The archive contains, at the most fundamental level, two sets of edited primary materials: Works and Manuscripts.

list.item: A work in this edition consists of a discrete text by Ruskin (e.g., a poem, an essay, a sermon, a mathematical proof), including all available witnesses of that text (each of these edited and annotated), and accompanied by the workʼs explanatory apparatus and available facsimiles.
A manuscript is a physical document manifesting Ruskinʼs texts, represented in the archive by its own explanatory apparatus in addition to the works that make up the manuscript.

div.p: As translated into Web pages, these two sets of materials form a given workʼs Work Pages, and a given manuscriptʼs Manuscript Pages (see Plan of the Archive). This organization arose from our determination editorially to strive for a double centeredness, reflecting a creative tension between Ruskinʼs composition of a unitary work and a dynamic conception of the collection containing that work.

Historically, a more static editorial approach to the early manuscripts was adopted by W. G. Collingwood, the editor of Poems (1891), and, following his suit, by E. T. Cook and Alexander Wedderburn, the editors of the Library Edition,. They divided the early writing by genre, poetry and prose, with Collingwood taking the lead by dividing his task into the Poems (1891) and a complementary edition of prose, the latter never realized under his editorship. Accordingly, in fashioning the first descriptive bibliography of the early manuscripts, “Preliminary Note on the Original MSS. of the Poems,” published as an appendix to the Poems (1891), Collingwood awkwardly set apart the verse manuscripts from the archive available to him, describing and chronologically ordering only those manuscripts (primarily the bound “notebooks”) containing poetry. The division is problematic even on terms of the “Preliminary Note” itself, which fails to explain the presence of prose genres contained within some of the manuscripts that it does describe, and which is altogether silent about manuscripts omitted from the list presumably because they contain solely prose.

In the Library Edition, Cook and Wedderburn addressed the problems raised by this division only imperfectly. The first two volumes fulfill Collingwoodʼs vision by housing early prose and poetry, respectively, but the former was a rough and ready repackaging of existing George Allen editions. They attempted no serious reexamination of the underlying approach; and in the second volume, “Poems,” the editors reprinted Collingwoodʼs “Preliminary Note,” expanding it with brief descriptions of some additional manuscripts, and with lists by title of the poems contained in the manuscripts, but without questioning the flawed logic of the division. Of the early manuscripts that they found written exclusively in prose, they bound some together with poems but omitted details about the prose pieces in their revision of the “Preliminary Note,” while they relegated description of other such manuscripts to the ”Bibliography” volume of the Library Edition, classifying these under “Juvenilia”—as if the early poetry manuscripts were not juvenilia (see History of the Bibliography and Editing of the Early Manuscripts).

Collingwoodʼs decision to divide the editorial task by genre is nonetheless historically significant, since Ruskin himself in his late autobiographical writing encouraged readers to conceptualize his career as divided between an early misguided ambition for poetry and a discovery of true vocation in prose. By prose, according to the later autobiographical writing of Fors Clavigera and Praeterita, Ruskin meant not the poetic prose of his youth, but the allegedly more analytical and plain prose by which he sought to position himself rhetorically. This account is faithfully reflected in fin de siècle biographical and editorial projects, even at the cost of distorting facts, such as Collingwoodʼs insistence that Ruskin started his writing life with scientific prose, despite the opposite picture revealed by Collingwoodʼs own careful chronological analysis of the manuscripts.

While the late‐century reception of the early manuscripts forms an important part of the discussion in the archive, ERM is organized editorially around a persistent phenomenon in the early writing that entails both the poetry and the prose manuscripts—namely, Ruskinʼs urge to conceptualize his compositions in terms both of a unitary work and of some larger anthology or collection containing it. In the Red Books of the 1820s, Ruskin projected his prose compositions as “volumes” in an ongoing multi‐volume series, while he filled out each of these “volumes” with poems collected as small anthologies. In the “Account of a Tour on the Continent of 1833‐34,” he collaborated with his father on what appears designed initially as a travelogue in verse, but then Ruskin re‐conceived the project as a composite genre, an anthology‐like travelogue in verse, prose, and picture. At the same time, along with increasingly complex composite projects, Ruskin observes generic boundaries in some poetic, scientific, and theological manuscripts of the mid‐1830s onward.

As Ruskin himself testified, the tension between work and anthology was a creative one, his process of composition and invention depending on simultaneous attention and resistance to bounding and containing structures. . . . Inevitably, the archiveʼs organization into Works Pages and Manuscript Pages tends to dispel these tensions by the effort to achieve clarity at those levels. In an attempt to represent some of the dynamic tension between container and contained, however, we have adopted an approach to encoding that describes Ruskinʼs nested structures at least within the confines of a single bound manuscript.

div.head: teiCorpus Markup and the Tension between Corpora and Works
div.p: To represent the competing integrity of the unitary work and of the anthology containing it, and even of anthologies containing anthologies, ERM uses the element 〈teiCorpus〉 combined with standoff markup using XInclude. Since 〈teiCorpus〉 can both contain and be contained by other 〈teiCorpus〉 documents, as well as contain other TEI documents, the element is the most available means of representing the double centeredness of the archive.

Typically, the highest‐level entity described as a corpus in ERM is the bound manuscript, which Collingwood likewise recognized as a basic unit of the archive, and which he numbered according to chronological sequence in his "Preliminary Note," using roman numerals (see Overview of Manuscripts). Cook and Wedderburn annotated the “Preliminary Note” with lists of titles of works contained in each of these manuscripts, an expansion that supplies the sequence of works as they appear in a manuscript (although not necessarily their order of composition), but that did fundamentally affect Collingwoodʼs editorial practice, which was present eclectic texts of single works, arranged chronologically. ERM likewise seeks to display and annotate single works (as documentary, not eclectic texts), but also to exhibit the context of Ruskinʼs strategies for inclusion in larger bounding structures such as anthologies, and anthologies within anthologies.

For example, in the originally blank, pre‐bound notebook that Collingwood named MS I, and that the Ruskin family knew as one of the Red Books, Ruskin used the inside front endboard to make a title page for a text, “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 1, which he possibly intended, at least initially, to be coextensive with the physical Red Book (see “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 1: Title, and MS I: Title). Having completed this installment of the prose work—a terminus that he declared by inscribing “end of harry and Lucy”—Ruskin extended the contents of MS I with an anthology, “Poetry”. This, too, reached a terminus declared by a colophon:

div.p: The colophon reflects the play of closure by doubly declaring an “end”—the second declaration, “end of the poems,” specifying the end of the anthology. This declaration is then erased (with a roughly scrawled strikethrough), apparently in order to mark the end of a larger entity. That larger entity may be understood as volume 1 of the prose work plus the poetry anthology, the latter appended to but distinct from that first prose “volume”; or the entity may be volume 1, which comprises both the prose work and the poetry anthology. Compounding the possible tensions, we do not know who scored through “end of the poems.” If not Ruskin himself, one of his parents may have “corrected” the redundancy—perhaps his mother, also added a kind of colophon of her own, which dated her sonʼs beginning and completion of the manuscript (Margaret Ruskinʼs Gloss on the Dating of MS I). Whoever was responsible, Ruskin violated both his motherʼs gloss and his own colophon by adding a new work to the inside back endboard—an emblem representing the “heights of wisdom” and “depths of folly,” which he dated a few months later. It was not the “end” of the Red Book, after all.

The 〈teiCorpus〉 markup represents MS I as a corpus containing other corpora made up of nested unitary works (TEI documents). Thus, for MS I, the markup uses 〈TEIcorpus〉 elements to describe two containers—the manuscript or Red Book as a whole, and the poetry anthology—with 〈xi: include〉 pointing to standoff markup of 〈TEI〉 files containing the texts, “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 1, and the six poems in the anthology.

Further, the standoff markup using 〈xi: include〉 accommodates the necessary complexity involved in representing the integrity of works as well as manuscripts. As explained in Plan of the Archive, a work in ERM is repesented by Work Pages, which comprise an Appartus Page discussing the work and Text Pages showing edited transcriptions and facsimiles of the various witnesses of that work. A manuscript is represented by an Apparatus Page, while its Text Pages are effectively the sum of the Text Pages for those witnesses contained within it, and of any Apparatus pages for corpora also contained within the manuscript—such as the Apparatus for the poetry anthology inside MS I. The 〈teiCorpus〉 element accommodates these various 〈TEI〉 document types in ERM—apparatus, witness, drawing, gloss, and so on—that make up the archive. Expression of corpora allows for interpretation of Ruskinʼs intention as unfolding rather than teleological and fixed. Here and in other instances, he seems to have been intrigued by corpora as provisional. In MS III—chronologically, the next Red Book he used after MS I—he worked simultaneously on volume 2 of the prose work, “Harry and Lucy,” which starts on the first page of the notebook, and on an anthology entitled “poetry discriptive,” which starts several leaves into the notebook. Thus, it appears that Ruskin did not just imagine filling MS III by running up one text, “Harry and Lucy,” against another group of texts, the anthology, but that he conceived the manuscript in terms of two corpora vying for the space between them. As it turned out, he left this volume of “Harry and Lucy” incomplete (a fate common to many of his works), so that the remaining blank leaves between the stop of “Harry and Lucy” and the start of the “poetry discriptive” anthology became available to enter two additional poetry anthologies and allow them to clash for space as well.

Other examples of provisional corpora include MS II, a handmade booklet that Ruskin compiled around the same time as MS III, and that he inscribed with the title “Works” at the top of the first page, suggesting perhaps that now that all his writing—MS I, MS II, and MS III, and perhaps unbound pieces too—formed a single corpus, like Wordsworthʼs cathedral with its tripartite naves forming the great philosophical poem and with the single poems ranged round as antechapels. By 1834, Ruskinʼs ambitions rose to the “Account of a Tour on the Continent,” which he modeled on the composite, anthology‐like genre of the illustrated travelogue, such as Samuel Rogersʼs Italy, and consisting of poems, prose, and his hand‐drawn imitations engravings and lithographs.

An older way of representing such collections in TEI would be to enclose texts with the 〈group〉 element, an element that does validate a representation of groups within groups, such as a poetry anthology enclosed within a manuscript that is itself conceived as a group. But because this element can nest only within a 〈TEI〉 document, and unlike 〈teiCorpus〉 cannot itself contain a 〈TEI〉 document, the 〈group〉 element is too inflexible to represent Ruskinʼs double centeredness of work and manuscript and their dynamic, evolving relation. Conceivably, the entirety of ERM could be encoded as a single corpus, with each manuscript forming a group, but this expression would conceal Ruskinʼs evolving intentionality as grandly and deceptively as Wordsworthʼs metaphor overwrote the provisional status of The Recluse.

The 〈teiCorpus〉 markup also allows for potentially reordering corpora athwart manuscripts, such as the “volumes” making up the uncompleted “Harry and Lucy,” drawn from MS I, MS III, and MS IIIA, or the poems, prose, and drawings forming the uncompleted “Account,” drawn from fair copy of two versions, in MS IA and MS IX respectively, and from draft in MS VIII. We could choose from the start to represent an eclectic text of “Harry and Lucy” or of the “Account,” by nesting the texts of the parts inside a 〈group〉 element, but this structure would assume a fixed rather than unfolding intention, requiring subordination of the separate texts to a common frontmatter, but that frontmatter, even if only implicit, would be an editorial invention. Ruskinʼs “volumes” of “Harry and Lucy” are related to one another only loosely, resembling less the volumes in Maria Edgeworthʼs Harry and Lucy; or Early Lessons Concluded, the book on which Ruskin modeled his title page, than the separate books in the series, each aimed at a successively older age group: Early Lessons, Frank, Harry and Lucy; or Early Lessons Concluded. Nonetheless, if one can argue for forming these volumes into a unified work, “Harry and Lucy,” the 〈teiCorpus〉 markup does not prevent such a move. Meanwhile, encoding each volume of “Harry and Lucy” as a corpus within MS I, MS III, and MS IIIA also expresses those volumesʼ relation to those respective corpora—a relation that is perhaps closer than that binding the volumes to one another.

Other texts potentially form groups in which the bonds between texts do appear stronger than their adherance to separate corpora in which they are found. The Sermons on the Pentateuch exist in fair copy in five handsewn booklets, while their drafts (some revised and fair‐copied in the booklets, and some unique) are contained in various Red Books. Because Ruskin entered these drafts in unused spaces in Red Books that he had abandoned some time earlier as an integral corpus—in some instances, the draft text of a sermon running reverso and upside down to the original contents of the Red Book—these drafts probably should not be interpreted in terms of the dynamic competition for space that characterizes Ruskinʼs composition of the corpora forming MS III. Again, 〈teiCorpus〉 markup does not prevent reordering of the sermonsʼ separate text documents into a whole, while also allowing the presence of the sermonsʼ drafts to be expressed in their various manuscripts.

In this markup, insertions by outside parties, such as glosses by Ruskinʼs parents are represented as “works” in themselves with TEI headers, when the glosses refer to the manuscript corpus as a whole. They are a file type named gloss, with an ordered presence in the manuscript, but not a hierarchical dominance:

By its placement in the midst of the poetry anthology, the gloss is ambiguous about what state the manuscript had achieved when Margaret pronounced it “finished.” The glossʼs declaration of completion was trumped, at the very least, by Ruskinʼs addition of the emblem on the inside back endboard, if not also by the two poems physically situated beneath the gloss on the page. Alternatively, Margaret may have timed her insertion of the gloss appropriately, if not positioned it so clearly, in response to Ruskinʼs signals of closure—his colophon, and his final poem in the anthology, “On the Rainbow”, which may pose its emblem of the rainbow as mirroing a drawing of a rainbow in the “frontispiece” of MS I, and hence strengthening appearance of closure—however provisional that closure turned out to be.

An apparent limitation of this approach to markup is that we are sometimes driven to representing such components of a corpus as the title “Poetry,” the head for the MS I Poetry Anthology, as a separate TEI document, since 〈teiCorpus〉 cannot accommodate such a textual element at a lesser level of granularity. But if it seems to stretch credulity to create a TEI document to witness a one‐word head, the solution is responsible to the provisional quality of Ruskinʼs title page for MS I, which may refer solely to the prose tale, but which may also refer to the prose tale plus the poetry anthology plus the emblem of the “heights of wisdom” and “depths of folly.” The “Account” lacks a main title in any of its manuscripts, even the fair copies, and the starting and ending point of its draft in MS VIII, amid drafts of unrelatied works, is ambiguous.

div.head: Expressing the Materiality of the Manuscripts
div.p: For Ruskin, was the physical Red Book containing MS I co‐terminous with “volume 1” of a compound text, consisting of a title page (oddly situated on the inside front endboard, a verso); the prose work, “Harry and Lucy”; the poetry anthology with its title and individual texts; the colophon; and the late‐added emblem? Ruskin seems keenly conscious of the uses of materiality—pre‐bound notebooks, ledgers, handsewn pamphlets, folded sheets—to set boundaries for texts, which he could both push against and accept as a constraint. Another justification for reliance on 〈teiCorpus〉 to define a manuscript is that its physical description can be encoded within the header for the highest‐level teiCorpus element (as well as described discursively in the Apparatus Page) that circumscribes a given manuscript—MS I, MS II, and so on—with the implication that these physical elements apply significantly to the various text corpora contained therein. Because Ruskin often imitated the material condition of a published codex in his manuscripts—lettering his fair copies in imitations of typographic elements such as title pages, colophons, pages with justified margins, and illustrating them with drawings that imitate the stippling of an engraving or the wash of a lithograph—the binding of a manuscript may prove as significant to express as the hand in which it is copied.

div.head: Collection and Anthology
div.p: Corpora range in levels of cohesion from collection to anthology. . . .

Ruskin thought of a class of manuscripts that the family called his Red Books as embodying collections that could be defined by beginnings and endings. “I am trying to get that red book of mine which has the Monastery in it finished, by the time you come home. I am putting in the shipwreck altogether and the adventures of an ant &c” (letter from John to John James Ruskin, 10 March 1829, RFL 192). What prompted these openings and closings in a given instance is a question of interpretation, but the boundaries often appear defined by the manufactured physical notebook.

div.head: The Documentary Editorial Orientation in ERM
div.p: At the levels of both the work and the manuscript, the editorial orientation of ERM is documentary. This approach contrasts with W. G. Collingwoodʼs in Poems (1891), which can be characterized as aesthetic in method, in the sense described by (Shillingsburg in Scholarly Editing in the Computer Age, although a more historical orientation developed when Cook and Wedderburn incorporated the Poems (1891) into the Library Edition. A documentary approach might seem to threaten the double centeredness sought in ERM by favoring the work over the manuscript, since documentary editing tends to treat each witness of a text as monolithic—annotated perhaps, but not amended (Shillingsburg, Scholarly Editing, 23), but in the design of the archive a documentary account of a given witness can be related either to the manuscript containing that witness or to the workʼs subsequent publishing history, if any.

Moreover, juvenilia as a field of study privileges a documentary rather than an eclectic methodology. The aim of documentary editing, as summarized by Mary‐Jo Kline, is to represent “inscribed artifacts whose unique physical characteristics and original nature give them special evidentiary value” (Guide to Documentary Editing, 2, and see 9). Writing in the mid‐1980s, Kline could still generalize a contrast between this approach and literary editing. Increasingly, literary scholars have adopted a more sociological approach focuseed on study of the artifact in its cultural moment, while historians have come to recognize that their allegedly purist documentary editing has always been more interventionist and “literary” than some wanted to claim, prompted apparently by the politics of academic discipline (see the introduction to the third edition of the Guide to Documentary Editing). The study of juvenilia foregrounds the merits that historians have traditionally claimed for diplomatic editing of manuscript documents while highlighting the difficulties of achieving the purity of a diplomatic method, on which some historians insisted while refusing to own up to ways in which they compromised that supposed purity.

Earlier editors of the Ruskin juvenilia apparently took for granted that readers would benefit by an almost opposite editorial orientation, the aesethetic. From John James Ruskin and W. H. Harrison, to W. G. Collingwood, to E. T. Cook and Alexander Wedderburn, the early editors freely and without acknowledgment changed punctuation, invented titles, revised lines and reorganized strophes of poetry, and joined fragments that are unrelated in the manuscripts to form texts that Ruskin never wrote (see History of the Bibliography and Editing of the Early Ruskin Manuscripts). These edited texts are encoded in ERM as witnesses contributing to a sociological representation of a given work, as they embody a conception of Ruskin’s boyhood as formed by Ruskin and his circle in the 1880s and 1890s.

In twentieth‐century editing of Ruskin, the orientation swung to a documentary method, prompted in part by Helen Viljoenʼs scorn for the methods of Cook and Wedderburn in the Library Edition. (She was less willing to point out similar faults in Collingwoodʼs editing, failing to situate either the Poems [1891] or the Library Edition in a context of the history of editing.) The results of this swing are reflected in Van Akin Burdʼs 0000 edition of the Ruskin Family Letters, which influenced Victorian studies by his insistence on treating the entire familyʼs historical papers—the family letters—as requisite to scholarship, and not just Ruskin’s literary accomplishment. Before Burd [Viljoen and the Bowerswell Papers]

div.head: Transcription
div.p: Whereas Ruskin's first editors were determined to regularize Ruskin's punctuation, later editors and critics, such as Van Akin Burd, attempted faithfully to reproduce Ruskin’s punctuation, on the grounds that one could detect the pulse of thought in his hand. Similarly, for Emerson, the lack of punctuation in Ruskin's early writing provided a window to how he “bound his phrases each to each” and allowed “their movement [to jam] back and forth in the mind” (RGI 27).

These movements of mind, if indeed reflected in Ruskin's punctuation or lack of it, are preserved in the documentary transcripts and accompanying facsimiles. Nonetheless, Ruskin's punctuation must be coherently and consistently encoded, especially in its idiosyncracies. Fortunately, Ruskin's inventions and oddities prove sufficiently persistent and consistent, at least for a period in the evolution of his hand, that they can be represented in XML/TEI more meaningfully than as an accidental.

Some of these marks are more accurately understood in terms of Ruskin's reflection of the materiality of the published texts that he imitated than as an expression of thought according to a Romantic poetics. For example, in order to imitate printed prose that is justified on both left and right margins, yet without having to achieve that effect in a given line of text by adjusting space between words or between letters within a word, Ruskin invented a mark that simply fills any remaining space in a line to the margin. In his earliest prose text, “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 1, the mark has the appearance of a dash of varying lengths, but it would misrepresent the mark to encode it as a hyphen, en-dash, or em-dash according to appearance. Rather, we encode this consistently as a geije of @type purposed for justifying text: <g type=“justification”>-</g>. In the MS IX fair copy of Account of a Tour on the Continent, the mark takes the form of a point combined with a dash: <g type=“justification”>.-</g>. We do not attempt to encode the varying length of this geije, as the length is apparent in the facsimile; and in any case, the mark's length is a function of its purpose of filling remaining space to the margin.

In practice, the justification geije is typically followed by tags indicating a line break or a page break; and the line break is the @type for "runover"--that is, the prose text spills over to the next line: Harry determined-
to go on with science and
There are instances, however, of Ruskin using the justification geije at the start of a line, rather than at the end. It seems in some texts that he did not like indentations for paragraphs; and if he did indent a paragraph, he filled in the space with his justification geije. Correspondingly, he used the justification geije to signal the end of a paragraph, so he could start the next paragraph flush left. Examples are found in

In some cases, what looks like the justification geije, and may effectively function as such, serves primarily to indicate a word division. These instances are encoded as a hyphen followed by a line-break tag, as follows: now I
will show you some experi‐
ments on sound. It is possible that, at this early stage, Ruskin did not clearly distinguish a word-division hyphen from a justification geijeFor the same reason, I ignore dots and fancy flourishes used to fill out and justify lines with the margin (unless, as in some cases, a flourish indicates the end of a paragraph) and other marks that serve only decorative or doodling purposes (e.g., a prominent dot raised above the line in the middle of a sentence where one would expect to find no punctuation, or stray horizontal lines that seem have occupied the writer in moments of abstraction). Where Ruskin omitted ending punctuation, I follow suit and supply extra space, as does Burd in RFL. I do indent paragraphs, although—whether to give the appearance of a solid block of text, or merely to save paper—Ruskin often indents only slightly or inserts a narrow extra line space at the end of a paragraph and brings the next one flush.

Rough drafts present the usual problems of transcription. Conjectural readings are represented in square brackets and with a query mark: for example, W[ho(?)]. When I cannot make out a word at all, I supply simply the query [(?)]. Words that Ruskin crossed out are enclosed in angle brackets: for example,. Double angle brackets indicate letters or words written over by other letters or words, although I have more often found it clearer to write out such explanations in the textual notes. I prefer to let stand, often without comment, Ruskin’s remarkably rare misspellings and grammatical errors, supplying [sic] only when the problem might appear to be my error. One error I do consistently and silently correct is Ruskin’s doubled letters arising from dividing a word between lines, and doubled words occurring before and after page breaks. Except where noted otherwise, I retain Ruskin’s capitalizations, ampersands, and spaces in words like to day, every day, and every one. Omitted letters usually are meant to serve poetic meter, both in rough and fair copy; however, when a missing letter is clearly an error, as in the prose works, I supply it in braces { }. The prose works, such as “Harry and Lucy” and the sermons, present special problems in their accidental features, precisely because the fair copies are on such good behavior.

A frequent oddity, perhaps related to Ruskin’s later idiosyncracy that Burd terms his “half-comma,” are periods in the place of commas in the middle of sentences. Conversely, commas often stand for periods at the end of sentences. This reversal is not consistent but occurs regularly enough that the modern reader should be made aware of it without having to translate the punctuation. My compromise is to substitute the customary punctuation in square brackets, so that the reader will understand that [,] means Ruskin used a period and that [.] means he used a comma. I substitute [.] for an ending comma, however, only when that punctuation is followed by a capital at the beginning of the following sentence; if independent clauses are strung together and divided by commas with no capitalization, I leave the commas.

In years prior to using the period and comma reversal, Ruskin evidently has trouble writing commas on the baseline, and they float like apostrophes and quotation marks. These marks are regularly interpreted as commas.

In the earliest writing, Ruskin appears to have developed some punctuation peculiar to himself—as obscure, in some instances, as his later mineralogical code symbols. In the first “Harry and Lucy” (no. 3), Ruskin ends sentences with a mark that might be a question mark or might be an exclamation point, and that seems to serve both of those functions. I have interpreted this mark similarly to my treatment of Ruskin’s comma and period reversal, using [?] for the mark when the sense calls for a question, and [!] for the mark in other cases.

As another system of his own in the earlier writing, especially in no. 3, Ruskin added closing quotation marks only to the ends of paragraphs, never paired with opening quotation marks. Not all the paragraphs with closing quotation marks are dialogue, and not all dialogue paragraphs have quotation marks. I suspect either that Ruskin misunderstood the symbol as indicating the end of a paragraph, or that he just liked the mark’s appearance. In either case, the mark would be best omitted altogether in transcription; however, I have retained it, since another reader might make better sense of it.

Still more bizarre is Ruskin’s doubled period, which he uses in the second “Harry and Lucy” (no. 20) and still more frequently in “Eudosia” (no. 27). The mark certainly does not indicate an emphatic stop; the opposite is more likely, a two-point ellipsis suggesting a slight pause, in the way a dash would normally be used. Ruskin may have needed to invent his own sign to function as a dash, since he used dashes and hyphens for another purpose, namely, to fill out and “justify” lines. In nos. 20 and 27, a bracketed dash [—] is used in place of Ruskin’s double period (..).

div.head: The Private, Confidential, and Public in the Early Manuscripts
div.p: In The Study of Modern Manuscripts, Donald Reiman recommends that editors “use different procedures for analyzing and editing private and confidential manuscripts from those they employ in presenting public documents.” Reiman defines these three categories, not by the depth of intimacy between writer and reader, nor by the intricacy of artfulness in the writing, but by “the nature and extent of the writerʼs intended audience. A manuscript is private if its author intended it to be read only by one person or a specific small group of people whose identity he knew in advance; confidential if it was intended for a predefined but larger audience who may—or may not—be personally known to or interested in the author; and public only if it was written to be published or circulated for perusal by a widespread, unspecified audience, including such abstractions as the nation, the reading public, and posterity” (Reiman, Study of Modern Manuscripts, 43, 65).

Which of these definitions applies to juvenilia and youthful writing, which often imitates public forms—even to the extent of mimicking the appearance of published documents—but which, in practical terms, cannot have been intended for an audience beyond the family circle? In considering an example of juvenilia, Jane Austenʼs Volume the First, Reiman proposes a special subcategory, “polished private and confidential manuscripts,” and frames the question regarding the intention of such artifacts in terms of manuscript authority. Nineteenth‐century juvenilia is special case among manuscripts belonging to an “age of printing” when professional “authors realized that their final manuscripts were way stations on the road to a perfected text, rather than the thing itself.” For mature, professional writers in the industrial age of print, “the manuscript no longer carried the same textual authority that it once had, even when it represented the authorʼs final involvement in such matters as the orthography and punctuation of most of the text.” Authors in the age of print “send their work to press . . . anticipating—and in many cases hoping—that changes in the text or its presentation will be introduced by the printers or the publishers.” Not so manuscript “poems or other compositions that were intended for the perusal of a few specific individuals—in short, private or confidential documents”—that the author fair‐copied for limited distribution, but did not intend for publication. These kinds of artifacts, typical of nineteenth‐century juvenilia, bear authority comparable to that of scribal copies of pre‐modern manuscripts, which “the writer never expected . . . to be superseded by a more authoritative printed text. Such a manuscript had to be more carefully prepared than a press copy, because it would neither be vetted by publisherʼs readers and compositors nor corrected in proof” (Reiman, Study of Modern Manuscripts, 92, 93, 94-95).

Reiman is referring to the authority of copytext; and he points to sensible measures for situating an artifact like Austenʼs Volume the First in the category of polished confidential or private manuscript: in this case, “since some neighbors and acquaintances whom [Austen] disliked seem to have been targets of her satirical thrusts, the manuscript was clearly not intended to circulate beyond Jane Austenʼs circle of like‐minded intimates, who alone could understand the point of these barbs and share the humor of them” (Reiman, Study of Modern Manuscripts, 94). Similar evidence is available of Ruskinʼs carefully prepared fair‐copy manuscripts circulating among a close circle of admiring and sympathetic readers, such as the couple, Richard and Mary Gray, who were intimate friends of Margaret and John Jamesʼs. “I should like Mr. & Mrs. Gray to see Johns letters,” Margaret wrote to her husband in March 1831, suggesting that, when John Jamesin his travels neared Glasgow, where the Grays had recently relocated, he “make up a small parcel and send also [the poems] the fairies—the lines on Jessy these on Lord Nelson[.] I do not know exactly what you have but any you might wish to send I could let you have—Weep for the Dead—O to My Heart I should like them to see” (RFL 232). For all of these poems, there survive fair copies in Ruskinʼs hand, and these were probably the manuscripts that Margaret deemed presentable for perusal by initimate friends—in Reimanʼs terms, the polished confidential manuscripts, bearing authority of copytext.

What does this classification indicate for the “different procedures” that, according to Reiman, should be observed in editing and analyzing private or confidential manuscripts as compared with public? First, the class of manuscripts that derive authority from both their polished presentation and their confidential status suggests that readers perceived authority in the material artifact itself, which bore direct witness to the authority of the writer—or of something about the writer. “I let Johns letters come just as he writes them,” Margaret explained to John James when enclosing their sonʼs letters inside her own, “that you may not be misled in your judgment as to his hopes and feelings” (4 March 1829, in RFL 185). Margaret assumes a Romantic idea about writing as an open window to the writerʼs expression, which if copied in her own hand would not only lose authority, but even potentially mislead the reader. There do survive copies of Ruskinʼs works in his parentsʼ hands, but these are far less common than Ruskinʼs own fair copies; and it seems unlikely that what Margaret wanted the Grays to "see"—not just read—would have been a fair copy in her own hand, which derived authority from her adult sophistication of punctuation, spelling, orthography, and the like. Rather, “judgment as to [the child writerʼs] hopes and feelings” derived from an intimate experience and knowledge that were available only through the authoritative original artifact; and by virtue of the artifactʼs materiality, this experience could be extended to a trusted confidential circle.

Evidence suggests that Ruskin shared this sense of an intended confidential audience that, to refine Reimanʼs defintion, was most likely "personally known to or interested in the author." Ruskinʼs understanding of these conditions is indicated by his inclusion of a letter to the Graysʼ relation, Mrs. Robert Monro, as part of MS II, a manuscript that he entitled “vol 1” of his “Works.” By including the letter as part of the handsewn pamphlet, which otherwise contains poems, Ruskin appears implicitly to invite Mrs. Monro to form part his confidential audience beyond the immediate family circle. The designation “Works,” moreover, attests to the significance of this production, both as a physical thing, a “volume,” and as an abstract promise of more to come.

It follows that, as an editorial procedure that Reiman calls for establishing in keeping with a manuscriptʼs classification, an edition of nineteenth‐century juvenilia should include manuscript images; diplomatic, and not eclectic or otherwise “corrected” transcriptions of texts; and a thorough physical description the manuscript. In fin de siecle editions of the poems and early prose, interest in the physical manuscripts was attested by facsimiles of selected pages, although the basis of selection was rarely made evident, and the sparseness of the facsimiles was doubtless legislated by cost. (Like illustrations, manuscript facsimiles on heavier stock were bound only into the large‐paper, quarto collectorʼs edition of the 1891 Poems, and not the inexpensive octavo edition; the Library Edition was designed solely as a collectorʼs set, differing only in the luxury of bindings.) The editors also supplied descriptive bibliographies of the manuscripts, although limited in detail, and aimed primarily at dating their contents. At the same time, the editors intervened heavily in the texts, improving them according to what they presumably deemed a public standard.

By this procedure, the earlier editors misled readers about the family context of Ruskinʼs writing, a context that Van Akin Burd . . . conbut also confused evidence of variations in that context. In Reimanʼs example of an editorial procedure inattentive to distinctions of private, confidential, and public status of manuscripts, Percy Bysshe Shelleyʼs poems were arranged “primarily by chronology, rather than by the authorʼs intentions,” resulting in indiscriminate mixing of “highly polished completed poems (with a few fragments) that [P. B. Shelley] released for publication with false starts and rejected fragments,” which “Mary Shelley had so assiduously rescued from his draft notebooks,” readers of these chronologically ordered editions inadvertently developed “a less positive picture of Shelleyʼs intelligence” (Reiman, Study of Modern Manuscripts, 43, 53-54). Fundamental as these distinctions between private, confidential, and public may be, however, juvenilia highlights ambiguities in an age of print rather than supplying a unique case of manuscript authority. As Reiman realizes, professional authorsʼ intentions about audiences can be ambivalent or ambiguous; and intentions, like the circumstances of reception, can change over time, even respecting the same document. In the case of juvenilia, these ambiguities can be as compounded as they are clarified by the apparently straightforwardly confidential status of a fair copy meant for circulation among intimate friends, since more than one cook is involved in making the stew.

Accordingly, in an edition of juvenilia and youthful writing, the greater the distance that the editor interposes between text and artifact, the less authoritative the transcription, by standards of the child writerʼs original circle.

Margaret classes some poems as confidential based on genre: what she “should like [the Grays] to see” are especially elegies, whether eulogizing family members (Jessie Richardson) or national heroes (Horatio Nelson), along with poems about childhood fantasy (fairies). Did she rein in the circle of confidentiality around other kinds of poems, or did she simply regard Ruskinʼs other productions as less worthy of regard? It was his parents, moreover, who decided the wider, if still select audience for the elegies along with whatever letters John James singled out for the “small parcel.“ Much or even most of the time, Ruskin may equally have taken that potential audience for granted. But some of the time, he may have regarded his letters as more narrowly confidential or some writings even as private, whatever his parents may have assumed.Even on the level of a unique manuscript witness of a given juvenile text, however, authority can be complicated by tensions. As remarked above, Ruskinʼs intentions included an awareness of tensions between competing boundaries of work and of manuscript, tensions to which he responded creatively; and his authority over text and/or manuscript was potentially shared—often willingly, sometimes submissively, and perhaps sometimes unwillingly—with his parents and, at times, with his cousin, Mary Richardson. These complications do not scuttle the basic usefulness of Reimanʼs categorizing of modern manuscripts by intended audience. Reiman

Circumstances could also tilt texts, and perhaps Ruskinʼs polished confidential manuscripts, toward the public. In the letter recommending her sonʼs writings to the Grays, Margaret reveals that John James carried many of these documents with him on his travels. Why? Did he cherish Johnʼs writings only privately, or could he be moved by fatherly pride to exhibit them to customers or fellow travelers? Hardly less speculative is the process by which some works, which had circulated in confidential manuscript, became publications by “J. R.“ As argued in the apparatus for “Account of a Tour on the Continent,” the precocious fair copy of this ambitious work might have gained Ruskinʼs entree to the man of taste, Samuel Rogers, and his celebrated palace of art.

div.head: The Scope of ERM
div.p: For a descriptive survey of the manuscripts planned for inclusion in ERM, see Overview of the Manuscripts.

Chronologically, a starting point for the scope of ERM would appear easily determined by the earliest available manuscripts in Ruskinʼs hand.
However, the elusiveness of beginnings was proved by Helen Viljoen, whose interest in Ruskinʼs early writings drove her farther back to his "Scottish heritage" in order to understand Ruskinʼs parents. The personalities and influence of John James Ruskin and of Margaret Ruskin, Viljoen believed, were foundational to any understanding of Ruskin as a writer (). ERM is not primarily a biographical resource, but an archive supporting the study of childhood and youthful writing, a purpose that narrows the scope to Ruskinʼs own writing, and not his parentsʼ and relativesʼ, except as othersʼ writing occurs in the early manuscripts. Still, if the study of childhood writing establishes a reasonable terminus a quo in Ruskinʼs own juvenilia, that aim opens up difficulties in determining a terminus ad quem for the archive.

The parameters proposed for many nineteenth‐century authorsʼ “apprentice” work point up the inadequate critical attention to juvenilia. As Juliet McMaster and Christine Alexander remark, in their contributions to a seminal collection on the nineteenth‐century child writer, the peculiarly pejorative connotations of the term juvenilia in literary criticism has caused, for example, the separation between the Brontë sistersʼ early writing (assumed to be inferior) and their novels (called "mature") to be regarded as a "problem" in a derogatory sense, with the juvenile understood to persist as a kind of infection into the later work. On the same uncritical grounds, the term juvenilia has been applied to the entirety of Branwell Brontëʼs work, although he died at age 31 ( 3, 71-72). The term continues to be applied quizzically to writers in our own time: in the 1970s, the publisher of the novelist Penelope Fitzgerald struggled to situate her first novel, The Golden Child, in the writerʼs corpus, declaring the work to be “the only piece of juvenilia I know of by a sixty‐one year old” (Gordon, "Cʼest quʼ elle a vécu"). Such pronouncements not only beg questions about the definition of juvenilia but also suggest an indifference to authorsʼ early writing as a critical focus.

Pejorative views of major authorsʼ childhood writing have a deep history, not least among writers themselves, and much remains to be studied in order to examine these prejudices critically. In this archive, hostility to the study specifically of nineteenth‐century writers is explored in attitudes surrounding (The Collecting of Modern Authors in the Late Nineteenth and Early Twentieth Centuries), a fin de siècle practice that significantly influenced the bibliography and editing of the Ruskin juvenilia. Whereas many “modern” authors expressed embarrassment about their juvenilia—and directed their anger at collectors who sought out early publications, and at the dealers, publishers, bibliographers, and editors who supported this collecting fashion—Ruskin willingly risked “whatever charge of folly may come on me” by printing his 1828 poem, “Glenfarg”, in The Queen of the Air (1869). The comment suggests that Ruskin, at least in his later writing, was unusual in giving any serious attention at all to the critical status of juvenilia; and his justification—that “the weak little rhyme already” demonstrated “all that I ever could be, and all that I cannot be”—suggests he would have considered an attempt to define the dividing line between juvenilia and mature work to be futile (Ruskin, Works, 19:396).

The difficulty of defining a terminus ad quem for juvenilia also returns us to Viljoenʼs enigma in establishing a starting point, in that the continuities of self that Ruskin claimed between his early and later writing reopen the question of continuities between the self who writes and others who write in response. In his masterful edition, The Ruskin Family Letters, Van Akin Burd included the full, available correspondence not only between Ruskin and his parents but also between John James and Margaret and even between the latter and their parents. Burd does not justify this inclusiveness directly, but allows the rationale to evolve implicitly from his critique of the biographical tradition, which had omitted reference to much of this correspondence. The critical issue, for Burd, was marked by Viljoenʼs identification of two, seemingly conflicting principles, which she perceived as setting the scope for materials included in the Library Edition: namely, that “nothing should be made public which might reflect adversely, from [the editorsʼ] point of view, either upon Ruskin or upon any member of the family”; and yet that “all that Ruskin said autobiographically, especially in Praeterita, about his life and that of his parents should be given unqualified editorial support” (). Burd shared Viljoenʼs determination that the first principle should no longer interfere with the second, but he also hinted that his publication of the full scope of the family letters would likely force a reassessment of Viljoenʼs rather strident views on the personalities of Ruskinʼs parents and their influence on their son. Particularly open to question on the evidence of the family letters was Viljoenʼs view of John James as a tyrant and narcissist (). Another possibility offered by The Ruskin Family Letters, which Burd did not touch on, but which the edition prompts, is evidence of collaboration between Ruskin and his parents in the early manuscripts—evidence that Viljoen, given her assessments of the parentsʼ personalities, was unlikely to detect, except in the form parental impositions on the genius of their son. An inherently collaborative aspect of child writing as a family enterprise, so obvious in the case of the Brontë juvenilia, is another insufficiently explored critical question that problematizes the scope of an archive of juvenilia.

Thus, in establishing the scope as well as editorial methodology of a corpus of juvenilia, the aim should be to encourage new questions about a category of nineteenth‐century writing that Alexander and McMaster call "almost a genre" (—questions that Ruskin and other Victorian writers recognized, if their responses were sometimes derisive, hostile, and dismissive. In ERM, the modifier early is based on a precedent set by the Library Edition, not because the editors were particularly thoughtful in their choice—"by ʼearlyʼ writings,“ they wrote, “is meant such as were composed previously to the first volume of Modern Painters," and they tended to use the term interchangeably with juvenilia ()—but because the neutrality of the term offers the advantage of leaving questions open for investigation. In Ruskinʼs early manuscripts, what is the relation between childhood writing and youthful writing? Between amateur status and professional writer? Between the personae of J.R., Kata Phusin, and the Graduate of Oxford? Between Ruskinʼs personae and the publications that featured them, and between these publications and the family circle in which Ruskin initially tried out these personae? Many of the publications that featured Ruskinʼs first publications placed him in dialogue—with artists and other writers in the literary annuals, and with amateur scientists in the Magazine of Natural History—and these dialogues may have been reflected the society of the minor art and literary professionals that John James hosted at the family dining table—presumably in part for his sonʼs benefit. To support such explorations, ERMʼs goal is to be as comprehensive as possible in scope and, as discussed below, flexible in editorial and encoding methodology.

At the same time, practical and reasonable limitations on the scope of the archive are set by the relation of the archive to other editions in Ruskin studies. Van Akin Burd granted permission for The Ruskin Family Letters to be incorporated into ERM so long as we maintained his editionʼs exact integrity. Burdʼs conditions effectively require a stand‐off, searchable electronic reproduction of his edition, a comparatively low priority since the edition remains so readily available in paper form. Moreover, thanks to the extraordinary quality of Burdʼs editing, there is no call at present for new transcription of the letters. When transcribing the juvenilia at the Beinecke Library, David Hanson checked the accuracy of Burdʼs transcriptions of the letters—not exhaustively, but sufficiently to conclude that this labor would result in only minor disagreements over the text of the letters. Thus, the scoope of ERM is limited to Ruskinʼs early writings exclusive of the letters.

ERM does re‐edit the poems contained in The Ruskin Family Letters, since Burd included only those poems whose fair copies could be considered epistolary presentations. For those works, Burd did not attempt thorough, systematic comparison or collation with drafts and other fair copies and published versions; and this thoroughness, including transcription and editing of epistolary versions, is the province of ERM. We have therefore captured images of Ruskinʼs letters to his parents at the Beinecke Library, as these are required to support the editing of the other juvenilia.

This division of labor with The Ruskin Family Letters also justifies ERM in taking Ruskinʼs “own” earliest writing in his hand as its starting point, without reaching earlier into family papers, except for purposes of annotating the edition. The endpoint of ERM reflects Burdʼs choice to close The Ruskin Family Letters in June 1843, when the first volume of Modern Painters appeared. Modern Painters I was also selected by the Lancaster University Ruskin Programme as the most productive starting point for a digital reediting of Ruskinʼs major works. This date remains a justifiable target for ERM, not only because publication of Modern Painters I represents a convenient and long‐standing fulcrum in Ruskin scholarship, but also because the range of 1826 to 1843 is sufficiently expansive for the reader to explore the definintion of juvenilia and related questions. Nonetheless, since Ruskin did not cease in 1843 writing poetry and publishing in the gift annuals, the investigation of his relation to this venue of publication requires extension of the scope in this one respect into the later 1840s. The manuscripts included are surveyed in Overview of the Manuscripts

Another superior published edition of an early Ruskin manuscript is A Tour to the Lakes in Cumberland, the account of the joint travel diary by Ruskin and his cousin, Mary Richardson, edited by James S. Dearden and Van Akin Burd. Again, as Burd and Dearden stipulate that any use of their editorial work is to be copied “as it stands, introducing comments or variants as an addendum” (Van Akin Burd to David C. Hanson, 14 August 2003; James S. Dearden to David C. Hanson, 3 September 2003), what would amount to a stand‐off, searchable reproduction of their widely available edition need not take high priority. However, inclusion of this manuscript in an electronic archive provides new benefits for investigating travel and collaborative writing in the Ruskin family, and therefore it is re‐edited on ERMʼs terms, while pointing the reader to Burdʼs and Deardenʼs edition as an invaluable complement. Less valuable from a textual standpoint is James Deardenʼs 1969 edition of Ruskinʼs 1830 Lake District tour poem, “Iteriad.” For copytext, Dearden relied on the transcript of Ruskinʼs fair copy that Cook and Wedderburn prepared for use in the Library Edition. While adequate for Deardenʼs intended audience at the time, general readers interested in the history of tourism in the Lakes, Cook and Wedderburnʼs transcript has little scholarly interest owing to its errors, the editorsʼ policy of freely repunctuating juvenilia, and their neglect of the poemʼs draft. Dearden has given permission, however, to quote from his lively notes for the edition. Unpublished scholarly attention to the juvenilia, which is quoted and referenced in ERM, includes the unfinished biography of Ruskin by Helen Viljoen, and her edition of the Sermons on the Pentateuch, now among the Viljoen Papers (see Spates, "Dark Star"; and Burd, "Ruskinʼs Testament of His Boyhood Faith").

Earlier editions themselves form a portion of the edited materials in ERM. For most readers, the primary source for the early Ruskin remains the first two volumes of the Library Edition, edited by E. T. Cook and Alexander Wedderburn, which in turn incorporate the Poems (1891), edited by W. G. Collingwood, and the editions of eqrly prose compiled by George Allen in the 1890s. The editorial inadequacies of these editions are discussed in History of the Bibliography and Editing of the Early Manuscripts, and below in The Documentary Editorial Orientation in ERM. Rather than simply displacing these editions, however, ERM treats their orientation to Ruskinʼs texts as itself historically and biographically valuable, reflecting fin de siècle attitudes (including Ruskinʼs own) about juvenilia in general and Ruskinʼs juvenilia and boyhood in particular. Transcripts of Collingwoodʼs, Allenʼs, and Cook and Wedderburnʼs edited texts are therefore included for collation and comparison with ERMʼs transcripts of the manuscripts.

Of course, the notes, bibliographies, and editorial apparatuses for these earlier editions contain much that is valuable—indeed, in some respects foundational—for editing the early manuscripts, and these resources are referenced throughout ERM. The archive also upholds Burdʼs and Viljoenʼs standards of rich annotation by quoting from family and related papers, as opportunity allows. Unpublished Ruskin manuscripts that have been transcribed for this use include: Ruskinʼs autobiographical reflections on his childhood and early writing, such as the manuscript of Praeterita; his correspondence with Sarah Corlass; and his correspondence with Susan Beever. Besides manuscript sources, rare printed sources include Ruskinʼs childhood books, some of which contain drawings and marginalia, and copies of the gift annuals, magazines, and other venues for his early publications.
